Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, my laptop open just out of sight, fingers itching to type the last section of my research report. My stepbrother nudged me, grinning as he tossed out ideas for our weekend—hiking, a movie marathon, maybe even a family barbecue. My stepmom’s eyes sparkled with hope, silently urging me to join in, to be present, to help knit our patchwork family closer. But my mind kept drifting to the looming journal deadline. The data needed one more check, the discussion section was unfinished, and my advisor’s reminder emails echoed in my head: “Accuracy is everything. No shortcuts.” I tried to laugh along, but my heart pounded with guilt. If I excused myself, I’d disappoint my family, reinforcing the distance they already felt. If I stayed, my research—months of careful work—might fall short of the standards I set for myself. The conversation swirled around me, and I felt split in two, torn between the warmth of belonging and the cold precision of my scientific duty.
